Award.AbstractNarration:
Algebras of chiral differential operators, a concept around which this project is centered, are in this class and were introduced by Schechtman, Vaintrob, and the principal investigator some 10 years ago. Here is the list of the main topics addressed in this project: 1. Gerbes of asymptotic chiral differential operators on smooth algebraic varieties. 2. Asymptotic chiral differential operators and localization of affine W-algebras. W-algebras and singularity theory. 3. Asymptotic chiral differential operators on singular affine algebraic varieties. Semi-infinite induction functor and string theory.

The present project belongs in the interface of mathematics, especially its algebro-geometric part, and modern quantum field theory. Classical mechanics is adequately described by such algebraic structures as Poisson algebras, quantization is usually satisfactorily reflected in geometric representation theory. The passage to fields drastically changes the landscape and, in particular, leads to such modern and still poorly understood concepts as a vertex Poisson algebra and a vertex algebra.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project belongs in a research area that can be vaguely called mathematical physics. A little more precisely it resides at the interface of  representation theory and string theory. In very general terms, representation theory is the mathematical tool intended to analyze symmetry. For example, if one wants to study functions on a sphere one is greatly aided by the fact that the sphere has a 3-parameter group of rotations. Similarly, symmetries of physics laws and objects are  fundamental  to our understanding of Nature. Interaction of mathematics and physics in this particular respect (as well as in many others) is especially fruitful. It is striking to notice that the same 3-parameter group of rotations arises as a group of symmetries of an elementary particle, and its representation theory leads to the quantum law of addition of momenta in a way parallel to which it facilitates the Fourier analysis of functions on a sphere.

This kind of mathematics/physics interaction received a huge boost with the advent of string theory and conformal field theory. What has happened is that an elementary particle, a point,  was replaced with a string - a curve - and so a trajectory, previously a curve, has become a surface, thus opening an avenue for the emergence of rather remarkable, infinite dimensional families of symmetries, such as Lie  algebras of vector fields or their relatives, algebras of functions with values in such groups of symmetries as were mentioned above, for example, symmetries of a sphere. These algebras are now best understood under the name of a vertex algebra.

I shall now try to put in this broad context one of the more recent results obtained as a part of this project. One of the more exciting  results in the physics study of instanntons was the discovery of the connection, quite unexpected, to vertex algebra theory. For a mathematician, what this meant is that similarly to an ordinary group acting on a space, such as sphere, hence on its cohomology, there is an action of a vertex  algebra on the cohomology of a certain infinite tower of ``spaces,'' known as moduli space. We have been able (jointly with A.Linshaw) to establish an interesting new structure on this sort of vertex algebra, a version of what is classically known as the Poisson-Lie group  structure. This is a new and, we believe, promising  point of view on the study of instanton moduli spaces.
